- Note what you notice: Is the metallic taste only on first draw after sitting, only hot water, or all taps all the time?

What the patterns usually mean
- Only first draw after overnight, improves after a 1–2 minute flush: likely your household plumbing (copper/iron) leaching a bit while stagnant; flushing is the fix.
- Only hot water: often the water heater or hot‑side plumbing. Try a hot‑water heater flush soon; don’t use hot tap for cooking/drinking.
- One faucet only: fixture/aerator issue.
- All taps, even after flushing: call the utility/HOA to check the distribution system; consider a test.

  - Any recent main work, hydrant flushing, source change, or chloramine switch?

  - NSF/ANSI 42 for taste/odor (chlorine/chloramine)
  - NSF/ANSI 53 for lead and other metals
  - NSF/ANSI 58 (RO) if you want broader reduction; more maintenance
  Replace cartridges on schedule.
- If you have a storage‑type water heater and it’s been a while, schedule a drain/flush; set temp 120–130°F to limit corrosion and bacteria while being safe.

- Fuel/solvent smell, strong chemical odor, oily sheen
- Brown/tea‑colored water with particles that doesn’t clear after 5 minutes of flushing
